service-mgmt/sm/src/sm_msg.c.message: Use sizeof(struct in6_addr) to be consistent with the other memcmp in this file.

Thanks Bin - that makes sense. If sin6_addr was changed to anything other than in6_addr, the code might be reading past the end of in6addr_any, so we'd be in a bad spot anyways. But I agree that using the sizeof the expression is better.

sizeof (expression) is better option in C++ compare to sizeof (type). Especially when the expression is not declared within the scope. Because the expression (in this case sin6_addr) could be redeclared to other type, compiler will not be able to detect the change and recompile won't fix the potential buffer overflow. 
I'd change sizeof (in6_addr) to sizeof (expression) instead.

etc/memcache.conf-sample.message:
Is this something that commonly needs to be configured? I've not really seen this as a config option outside of TLS terminators; usually clients handle negotiation on their own pretty well...

With that in mind, it seems weird to be able to specify ciphers but not TLS protocol numbers; if we keep this (though I'm not saying we should), should that be configurable, too?

The FIPS-compliance context is good to know, thanks for that. If you haven't already seen it, you may be interested in https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/751966, too.

Are we trying to make this work when the memcached server is FIPS-compliant (in which case ensuring the server can trim ciphers seems sufficient), when the swift memcache client is FIPS-compliant (in which case it seems like it would be necessary that we be able to trim TLS 1.0 and TLS 1.1 here), or both?

Is it not the sort of thing that can be set system-wide down in /etc/crypto-policies/ somewhere?

---

Side note: the deprecations in the ssl module leave me rather confused. From the ssl.PROTOCOL_TLSv* descriptions I see

> Deprecated since version 3.6: OpenSSL has deprecated all version specific protocols. Use the default protocol PROTOCOL_TLS with flags like OP_NO_SSLv3 instead.

But then from the ssl.OP_NO_TLSv1_* descriptions I'm just told

> Deprecated since version 3.7: The option is deprecated since OpenSSL 1.1.0.

I guess the best advice is from ssl.OP_NO_TLSv1?

> ... use the new SSLContext.minimum_version and SSLContext.maximum_version instead.

...but then those warn that

> Note: This attribute is not available unless the ssl module is compiled with OpenSSL 1.1.0g or newer.

So I'm not really clear on what the recommended way *would be* to trim TLS versions, particularly if I want it to work on a variety of distros which cover a range of openssl versions 😕

I believe this was added to oslo.cache (which I modeled this on) for FIPS compliance.

I know that all FIPS endpoints should be TLS 1.2 only from 2021, not sure about the clients.

Moises should know the details...
Yeah, cyphers are there in case we need to trim them in the future for FIPS compliance.

specs/wallaby/port-forwarding-port-range.message: nit: I understand that in the API we want to see port ranges at the exact same place, where we had ports before. However in the DB wouldn't it be better to decompose the range to start and end? For example it can make the no-overlap constraint simpler. Or to make sure that "port N" and "port range N:N" (which are technically the same) cannot be represented internally in two different ways.

Hi Bence, I agree with what you mean about having different columns to range's start and end, I see this point and it seems to be more natural to doing it in this way (storing the start and the end of ranges in different columns), so I changed the spec to store the ranges in different columns.

Thanks.

Problem with that new db schema is that You want to delete columns "external_port" and "internal_port" - this will fail in the db migration scripts as such operation should go to the "CONTRACT" phase which isn't allowed in Neutron since couple of cycles.
So IMO You should keep old, legacy fields and add new ones. I know we will have duplicate data there but I don't see any other way to do it in alembic.

Pedro, I was re-reading this one, and thinking.
Don't we need to extend the OpenStack SDK and python client to support this new api?

I believe there's no need to support this in python-neutronclient - there's no support for floating IP port forwardings at all there.

The SDK on the other hand seems to be in need of some updates:

https://opendev.org/openstack/openstacksdk/src/commit/4913b61713e39e7252c914c5fd476a71a9176106/openstack/network/v2/port_forwarding.py#L41-L44

Yes, I checked the python-openstackclient project and we will need to extend it too, to allow ranges, it accepts string but it validates the value as an integer between 1-65535, so we will need to change this validation to accept and validate ranges.

I did not see an example of a response for this request. It will create 100 port forwardings? Or just one with new style of port range for internal_port and external_port?

or a reponse like this:

Alright, for this style we can not call it "extend", this is totally changed the original data format. IMO, this can cause some backward compatibility issues for cloud API users. Since the key does not change, the value changed from int [1] to a string port range.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/network/v2/index.html?expanded=create-port-forwarding-detail#floating-ips-port-forwarding

So if we are not going to handle the API backward compatibility, it's better to add the "REST API impact" section to highlight the incompatible, [1] is an example.

[1] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/neutron-specs/specs/juno/neutron-ovs-dvr.html#rest-api-impact

I did not find any consensus that we are not going to make the API backward compatibility. For the existing cloud APPs this cloud cause the extra works for rewriting the code. For the compatibility maybe we can implement it like this:
1. still allow the original API input, for internal_port and external_port, it is still integer, but make them optional
2. add new api input attribute, external_port_range and internal_port_rang which accept string port range, also optional
3. for the port_forwarding plugin, it will check the API input
   a. if it is the original style, a one port integer port forwarding, noting changed
   b. if new range style, create range port forwardings
   c. if both are spplied, raise RequestError
   d. if no integer port nor string port range, raise InvalidInput

tripleoclient/v1/overcloud_deploy.py.message: How is this relevant with the THT parameter ContainerImagePrepare? If the parameter ContainerImagePrepare is not provided, then it should not trigger the image prepare - right?
No because on update it's a stack patch meaning this value always exists.

There are 2 image prepare tasks invoked during deployment

1) to prepare image parameters in tht
2) to pull images from source registry and then store it to local registry when local_destination is true

Current patch disables only 1 and asuues that ContainerImagesPrepare parameter in deployment templates has empty value, which should result the 2nd task skipped.

To be more safe, maybe we can 

1) implement a new parameter in tht to disable 2nd task and inject that parameter when --disable-container-prepare is set

or

2) implement a validation which errors out when ContainerImagesPrepare has any content when --disable-container-prepare option is set.

playbooks/publish/run.yaml.message: why is this made into a var, but not taken through to completion (ie, being able to drive it?). It would be great if the above shell was updated to take the latest stable release in the 3.x series.

if you set this to an empty string (ie: "") and put the following at line 19:

if [ -z "$HELM_VERSION" ]; then
  HELM_VERSION="$(curl -Ls https://github.com/helm/helm/releases | grep 'href="/helm/helm/releases/tag/v3.[0-9]*.[0-9]*\"' | grep -v no-underline | head -n 1 | cut -d '"' -f 2 | awk '{n=split($NF,a,"/");print a[n]}' | awk 'a !~ $0{print}; {a=$0}')"
fi

then unless a specific version is requested, it will always use the latest helm release.

also add `set -ex` at the start of the script to both show working, and not tolerate failure.

Why having differents vlan per rack?
If the vlan between compute and rack switchs would be only local (not configured accross racks), then it would be possible to have only 1 vlan for this?

Each time a new rack is deployed, a new "infrastructure" range (ie: the IPs for next HOP) must be created, so it wont simplify. However, for clarification, I've just added a note saying it's possible to use the same VLAN ID for all racks.

This really is a per-node, depending on the rack, configuration. If a network node is in rack b4, then here we should write "b4" or "physnet-b4" (it doesn't mater, as long as it matches what one writes as physnet when creating the segment).

There's nothing that has to be configured in the neutron-server (ie: neutron-api or neutron-rpc-server) side that depends on the physical network names.

I am confused.
IIRC the plugin is supposed to be configured on server side, not on agent side.
What needs to be configured on agent side is the mechanism driver (/etc/neutron/plugins/ml2/openvswitch_agent.ini).

So I would expect a config on server side (plugin) with all physical networks:
network_vlan_ranges = physnet-rack1,physnet-rack2

And a config on agent side with *only* the necessary bridge mapping:
bridge_mappings = physnet-rack1:br-ex

or something similar.

Would you mind double check this config on your side, or let me know if I am completely wrong?

I know that You can configure here various ranges for various physical networks. I just wanted to highligh that this setting should be configured on the node where neutron-server is run as only neutron server is using "network_vlan_ranges" config option really.

Did you mean the VMs under same router should be limitted to one rack? If not, the router connected (set external gateway action) to the provider-network will be created not only in rack1 but also in rack2. Then I can imagine some issues:
1. if switches of rack2 (switch 3 and 4 in the picture) also enable the segmentations of rack1, the broadcast domain will still get larger. It is the problem current Neutron is facing.
2. if rack2 not enable the rack1's segmentations, then the nova needs to limit the VM scheduling scope. Otherwise, the floating IP traffic can not work.
3. different neutron-bgp-speaker on different should create different peer for each rack, but in the details below, it does not.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Results of segragation with https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ci/+/761188

There are two cases we need to consider - branchless/tripleo-ci repos and tripleo-everything-else.

For the branchless repos we have nothing to gain as can be seen at [1]. This is because of the tripleo-multinode-branchful
template [2] that explicitly brings all the content providers (to the yard). 

For tripleo-everything-else we further distinguish master vs stable branches. For master we have the most significant improvement as can be seen at [3]. We only need to run 2 content providers - master and latest stable/ (currently victoria in [3]). 

For stable/ branches in tripleo-everything-else repos we still run 3 content providers as can be seen at [4][5]. This is because the upgrade jobs use the stable and stable-1 content providers, but we still have the 'master' version for the rest of the jobs. In this case, the 'master' and latest stable versions of the content provider are the same e.g. [6] vs [7] from the victoria test @ [4], they are both building the same victoria hash. Not clear however how we can define the layouts to remove this extra content provider.

roles/bindep/tasks/install.yaml.message: For zuul.ansible.com, we don't want to install virtualenv from pip, but use the distro package. I think what we want to do here, is make a new ensure-virtualenv role, that can support both pypi, package, maybe even from source.
Please look at latest patch, I completely changed the logic of this section.

This is more an ansible dependency, then bindep, TBH. With that in mind, I'd prefer not to see this added into this role. In the case of centos-8, we just enabled it for zuul.a.c jobs, and this works as expected because we include pip and virtualenv still in our images. I really think for now, openstack-infra should do the same.

I think we need a spec that talks about how images needed to be bootstrapped with ansible dependencies, or a new role close to add-ssh-keys that does it (either via pip or packages).
Doing this would explode the scope of the change. Instead I will add --user which will avoid touching the system package.
I'm not sure why we need to do this since the pip module supports virtualenvs? https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/modules/pip_module.html#parameter-virtualenv
It supports virtualenv IF the virtualenv command is availab. See: https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/modules/pip_module.html#parameter-virtualenv_command
yeah, I mean we can install virtualenv and then use the pip module, we don't need to run it through the shell.

This is what the [1] ensure_pip_virtualenv_cmd is supposed to do for us.  If use use ensure-pip here, we can install this and just sent "virtualenv_command:" in the pip below to '{{ ensure_pip_virtalenv_command }}'.

that way, we do not bring in virtualenv packages if they are not required, which is basically everywhere these days, as venv suffices.

[1] https://zuul-ci.org/docs/zuul-jobs/python-roles.html#rolevar-ensure-pip.ensure_pip_virtualenv_cmd
I read your comment 3 times and I still don't understand why you put a -1. What is the problem that you want to avoid?

We are trying to avoid bringing in virtualenv on our base CI images.  This role should call ensure-pip first and then install into an environment using 'ensure_pip_virtualenv_command' which this role provides.

Ian, I would be really useful to make more clear comments.


At the time this PR was raised ensure_pip_virtualenv_cmd did not exist at all, at at least it was not documented, I checked.
You could probably set the virtualenv_command here instead of creating the virtualenv through the shell.
I did, but I didn't understand it at first. Looks good to me then.

Did you read my comment at line #9 ?
Avoiding virtualenv_command is by design, mainly because of https://github.com/ansible/ansible/issues/52275

The first version of Ansible that works well with it is 2.9.8

roles/bindep/tasks/packages.yaml.message:
I'm not seeing this tested, and TBH I'm not convinced that it works?  If you serially install 

 epel-release <package-from-epel>

then dnf won't have updated its indexes after the epel-release install and so won't know what's in the repos?

Couldn't the existing profiles model, split into two steps handle this without bindep changes?  We can add repo packages in a "pre" or "repos" profile that is run before the main install?
Just put those packages in a pre-test profile instead of a test profile, and we can adjust the role to install pre-foo in a separate phase before foo?
I think it might just be easiest to have this role look for a bindep-pre.txt file first, and then a bindep.txt file.  that seems to require no changes.

Package module uses platform specific modules so for yum/dnf at least it will default to not update the cache on each run. update_cache defaults to false.

I am aware about current approach limitations, the big question is how to add this extra functionality in bindep wihtout breaking backwards compatibility? Once we decide how to change bindep, we can update this role to make use of it.

To my first comment; I guess that "package:" refreshes the metadata before every install, although I couldn't find documentation that explicitly states that.  That probably makes it quite painfully slow ... It would be good to have this tested.

Overall, I don't know about using stderr as a metadata communication channel.  Especially when we have a series of more standard ways we could deal with it, and the result is at best terrible performance for most centos/rhel package installations.

I guess you are saying you'd have

 epel-release [platform:rpm pre-epel]
 package-from-epel [platform:rpm epel]

So you run once with "pre-epel" and then again with "epel"; the second run epel packages are available.

How could we generalise that though?

Another suggestion is

https://review.opendev.org/753198

which shows packages *only* for profiles listed on the command-line.  So you would have 

 epel-release [platform:rpm pre-install]
 package-from-epel [platform:rpm]

and this role would have to first do a install-run with *only* pre-install packages, and then a regular install will "just work".

Yet another suggestion is to just have a separate pre-bindep.txt and by convention do two bindep runs here, and install from that first.

hrm, so reading again the profiles are additive, so for example selecting "test" profile does all the base packages + the test packages.

Still ... if bindep got an "--only-profile" or similar flag ...

tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_create_adm.message:
We're already concatenating tripleo_admin_pubkey into the authorized_keys file in authorize_user.yml, but this is different. We're creating the id_rsa.pub which is symmetric to the id_rsa installed by the previous task. This is harmless if you're going to distribute the private key anyway and it's also useful. In this case, I'm using it with cephadm for the command below which run as the ceph-admin user. I can't just pass "--ssh-public-key ~/.ssh/authorized_keys" as that's something different.


$ sudo cephadm bootstrap \
     --ssh-private-key ~/.ssh/id_rsa \
     --ssh-public-key ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub \
     --ssh-user ceph-admin \
     --mon-ip $IP

deployment/swift/swift-base.yaml.message:
I was only able to test this patch in a Queens POC, with this patch manually applied on it.

Result: Success. 

In an environment deployed with env file (1), I could not see the prefix being accidentally reverted to an empty string if no SwiftHashPrefix was passed... 

(1)
~~~
 parameter_defaults:
   ControllerExtraConfig:
     swift::swift_hash_path_prefix: secret-prefix
~~~

I've deployed multiple times, with different patterns, but I can confirm that:

(for each controller node)
- manually cleaning up swift_hash_path_prefix from /var/lib/config-data/puppet-generated/swift/etc/swift/swift.conf 
- deleting /etc/puppet/hieradata/controller_extraconfig.json
- and then issuing multiple deployments using the following environment file (2).

(2)
~~~
parameter_defaults:
    SwiftHashPrefix: new-prefix-through-tht-param
~~~

still resulted in the original prefix being applied: i.e. operators that manually set a prefix, using this template without passing a value, will not incur into problems.

~~~
[heat-admin@controller-0 ~]$ sudo -i
[root@controller-0 ~]# cat /var/lib/config-data/puppet-generated/swift/etc/swift/swift.conf 
[swift-hash]
swift_hash_path_suffix = xxx
swift_hash_path_prefix=secret-prefix

[swift-constraints]
max_header_size=8192

[root@controller-1 ~]# grep -ir prefix /etc/puppet/hieradata/
/etc/puppet/hieradata/service_configs.json:    "gnocchi::storage::s3::s3_bucket_prefix": "",
/etc/puppet/hieradata/service_configs.json:    "swift::swift_hash_path_prefix": "new-prefix-through-tht-param", <====
/etc/puppet/hieradata/service_configs.json:    "tripleo::profile::base::swift::ringbuilder::raw_disk_prefix": "r1z1-",
/etc/puppet/hieradata/controller_extraconfig.json:    "swift::swift_hash_path_prefix": "secret-prefix" <=====
~~~


Being said that, in this exact environment I was not able to actually override the original prefix using (2).

I'll test again in an environment that has no swift_hash_path_prefix set through (1), and confirm that swift_hash_path_prefix is properly set to the value of SwiftHashPrefix.

>1) The SG ID it tries to delete was actually EXISTING in the past. 
This is almost same as test_delete_not_existing_security_group, neutron or nova proxy APIs operation or code path does not make any difference on trying to delete 'never existing' or 'currently not existing' sg. both are same case and they 404 if they do not find the requested sg id in DB.

# Test tries to remove not associated, but existing security group from VM.
Both cases are trying to "remove SG from ID" (unassociate) and not to simply delete the SG like and existing API test does, that's the reason for having VM created.

I don't think it is the same as test_delete_not_existing_security_group test. This one is trying to detach not existing SG from the VM (port) and the one mentioned by Brian is simply calling Neutron API to try to remove SG from the Neutron DB.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
I don't think this should be generally recommended.  It's not at all certain at this point that every project should have merge errors reported.  For example. OpenStack does not report merge conflicts to ansible.  For that reason, as well as the fact that in later versions of gerrit, it's no longer necessary, OpenStack does not enable the merge-check pipeline globally.

Further, the goal of getting a report on the initial configuration of a project-pipeline shouldn't depend on the merge-check pipeline.  It shouldn't require a noop job either.  It should be sufficient to add any project for which you want to receive config error messages to the check pipeline with an empty jobs list (jobs: []).  That might be a more suitable candidate for this recommendation.  Also, if you want to procede with this, you may want to suggest using the project regex to apply the template to all projects at once, if the circumstances are suitable (again, openstack wouldn't do that for ".*" because of ansible and other third-party-check projects, but we might do it for "^openstack/.*" etc).
Thank you for the suggestion, next PS uses that.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: s/operators/developers/g

Currently this is the only documentation of the methods we expect watchers to implement, right?

What are the possible values for audit_type? policy_index and object_metadata seem likely to be ints and dicts, respectively. Is there an easy way for developers to get the policy name? Whether it's EC or replicated? What keys should we expect to have available in object_metadata?

Maybe we could provide a simple no-op watcher that developers could subclass, and include more info in the docstrings.

Suggest adding *args, **kwargs to the expected method signatures to allow for future params to be added without breaking watchers.

Also, as mentioned in another review, I'd like to have the audit_location passed. I haven;t tried too hard but I don't think the metadata and policy is sufficient to let me find construct a diskfile for the object - e.g. if I wanted to change some metadata, like a crypto re-keying process for example...
The kwargs now must be named "storage_policy_index" and "metadata".

etc/object-server.conf-sample.message: It seems like we should call out that these must be "swift.object_audit_watcher" entry points.

Should we maybe also mention that each watcher spawns a new Python process? A comma-separated list in a config file kinda makes this feel like a lightweight thing, and doesn't scream "hope you have the processors and memory to deal with this" quite like I'd expect.
Would be helpful to also document here the entry-point group name where they are expected to be registered

swift/obj/auditor.py.message: I think it would be useful to call see_object() with the location of the object as well
From https://review.openstack.org/#/c/208222/ I think we want warning(), not warn().
Do we have a feeling for how long a watcher has to process an item?
Just to confirm: .exception() will include the traceback and exception name automatically, right?
Should we at least log the exception? Otherwise, I think it'll be pretty hard to debug watchers...

Passing the watcher the conf dict does not help the watcher with options that are not in config where default values are used - I'd prefer to see the watcher passed a dict of the actual auditor parameters (see also comment below about needing to pass a conf *new* dict to watcher).

Huh, it was worse than I previously thought:

  AttributeError: 'LogAdapter' object has no attribute 'warn'

OK, good design. But it means that the auditor->watcher communication is unreliable (since its using Queue.put_nowait) so a watcher can never be sure if it has missed objects during a cycle (start->end). I realise that often/usually the device contents are changing dynamically as the auditor runs, so there is no concept of "all objects have been visited", but there may well be uses cases (e.g. watching for objects in a retired policy or account, watching for objects older than T) where the watcher would really like some confidence that is has seen all objects that it may be looking for.

That could be helped by passing watchers the 'total_files_processed counter either as a param to see_object and/or as a param to end().

Also, maybe its worth trying a little harder to get the start and end messages onto the queue? Or, assign each AuditWorker a unique id and pass it with see_object calls...so the watcher has some clue as to where the auditor has got to wrt objects processed, cycles repeated...

OK, so i don't know the answer, but hopefully you can understand my concern.
max_queue_size is never passed with an arg - was the intention that this might be a configurable size?
If you change this to a more abstract name like "see_target" and add support for *args/**kargs this watcher wrapper becomes usable for account and container watchers too.

The thought crossed my mind, but do you think the protocol should be the same across all watchers? Notice that accounts do not have policies. One can always supply None, but it only means you're creating an artificial polymorphism where it's not existing naturally.

But on the other hand accounts and containers are in a sense objects, so even if we extend this to all types of objects, "see_object" continues, to apply.

I think we need more plugin implementations first, and bikeshed this names of methods when the bulk is done.
Full is not an attribute of multiprocessing.Queue, look like it needs to be imported from Queue package

It would be prudent to pass the watcher a *copy* of the conf so that the auditor is isolated from any changes the watcher class might make to the conf dict.

I guess the same concern applies to the logger, but I'm not sure quite what to suggest there.
could set a 'running' flag here and not bother filling the queue if running==False because the watcher failed to be instantiated.

Do we expect that most watchers will want to watch both audit types?

If not, should we provide a way to have the watcher tell us to skip it as part of start()? exit() and sys.exit() will just get ignored in the except.

I guess there's still os._exit() but that seems heavy-handed. I suppose we've already designed this to be extremely isolated... so maybe it doesn't matter. At the very least, though, we should document that as the expected (only?) method of early termination.
I still think it's worth logging the exception rather than relying on developers to properly wrap start/see_object/end in try...except clauses on their own.
While no longer strictly *necessary* (at least on tip-of-master), it'd probably still be good to have this use self.logger.warning()
We never use this dict. Was the intention to move everything in _feed_item_to_watcher() to using **kwargs like is done in the see_object case? If so, we should update start() as well.
Done
Still want to isolate this, per Alistair's suggestion.

I'd still like to see a way (other than os._exit()) for a watcher to signal that it doesn't care about this audit type. Alistair's 'running' flag idea seems like it may be useful; then we could just say

 self._running = bool(watcher.start(audit_type=audit_type))

here and change the loop above to

 while self._running:

Alternatively, we could make our sentinel value a little more explicit and have something like

 for item in iter(self._queue.get, None):

and separately break if not running.

Maybe worth doing something like

 for item in iter(self._queue.get, None):
It should probably use common.utils.load_pkg_resource()

It'll change the config a bit, from

 watchers = some_watcher

to

 watchers = some_package#some_watcher

but ultimately, I think that namespacing is probably a good thing. Will fix.
Done
I prefer the process to crash than to not do what the operator think it is doing. At least if the process is not running, the operator has a chance to see it in his monitoring
Yeah, that's fair. Will fix. (In fact, I think we may get this for free by switching to load_pkg_resource()...)
Totally *did* fall out of the load_pkg_resource goodness.
For something that will run for hours/days/weeks, only allowing 1 seconds of extra time seems rude, no? I would make it at least configurable.

1s between SIGTERM an SIGKILL actually seems not-too-crazy to me... but yeah, we should probably make the timeout between sending the sentinel and SIGTERM

- longer -- the poor subprocess may have a couple hundred items still to process -- and
- configurable.

What would a good default be? 10s? 30s?

Done

Now configurable, as watcher_term_timeout and watcher_kill_timout.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/agent/manage.message: An alternative would be to only update_local_puppet_cache() if this succeeds (i.e. in 'else' clause of try).  As the config_applied uuid would then be aligned with the puppet cache. Was this considered?

> An alternative would be to only update_local_puppet_cache() if this succeeds (i.e. in 'else' clause of try).  As the config_applied uuid would then be aligned with the puppet cache. Was this considered?

The cached hieradata is not really part of the configuration. If we only update local cache when the configuration change succeeds, then if the configuration apply fail, the cached hieradata would differ from the ones in /opt directory. So I'm thinking keeping cached hieradata consistent with the ones in /opt probably in any situations is more important.

But I'm open to relocate the update function for success case only.

Thanks for the clarification.  I see it's ok to align with the values in /opt since that is what will be mounted and downloaded to be applied; (and, if there is a config error it'll need to be reconfigured such as from api).

bsp-files/kickstarts/pre_disk_setup_comm.message: This code should not belong to 【# Avoid wiping USB drives】related functions.Should add own function description information

This should be a single grep:
pvs | grep -q -e "${dev}${part_number} *ceph" -e "${dev}p${part_number} *ceph"

What happens if WIPE_CEPH_OSDS is true ? This is the case on host reinstall when we wipe everything.
You should move the code inside if on line 173.

Also, when WIPE_CEPH_OSDS is true, since this is an LVM disk use the approach on lines 110 - 133 (removing each LV and PV.) Moreover, since these disks are going to be reused afterwards, unless wipe is done on volume creation, you will have to wipe the beginning and end of each logical volume before deleting it to make sure that there is no stale data in them. An approach similar to the way done for partitions:

Example:
        dd if=/dev/zero of=$part bs=512 count=34
        dd if=/dev/zero of=$part bs=512 count=34 seek=$((`blockdev --getsz $part` - 34))

/COMMIT_MSG.message: is re-applying puppet with this flag set to 'true' supported when the system has been deployed with a 'false' flag set already?
Yes

I don't think we want the user to be able to change this so I don't think we should be creating a service parameter. The etcd security should be enabled by default on an install and we do not want to make it possible to disable it after the fact.

Actually, we don't want it to be disabled.
As discussed in our design spec, this is mainly for upgrade scenario. 
When we upgrade from current version without secured etcd to the next version with secured etcd, we need this flag to judge 
and trigger restarting etcd with security after upgrade-activate.

A service parameter is not appropriate for this because:
1. It should not be changed.
2. It shouldn't be displayed to the user.
There must be another way of detecting whether the secure etcd configuration is active.
This should be "Closes-Bug" for proper linkage
Done

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/conductor/ma.message:
Unfortunately, I think this is going to result in a race condition where the runtime manifest could run on either controller first (or at the same time). I think that will lead to failures in some cases as both attempt to reconfigure the kube-apiserver or if the standby controller attempts to access the secure etcd before it has been configured on the active controller.

I would like input from others here (John, David, Don), but I think a solution may be to change your upgrade script to do all the work for the active controller (apply the etcd.pp manifest to reconfigure etcd and reconfigure the kube-apiserver to use the secure etcd). Basically going back to what it was doing before you made the last set of changes. Then the runtime manifest will only have to do work on the standby controller.
Agree with you, I can move that logic to here again.

Hi Bart,
However, I found that if I apply runtime manifest first on standby controller, it should be OK.
api-server in standby side could not access https, it will resume after runtime apply finish on active controller side and security etcd enabled.
So we need apply them almost at the same time. Otherwise, one api-server will lost connect for a long time. I'd like to keep current design. Any further comment?

If upgrade runtime manifest application failed, will it report any alarm to let user know it?
How we handle this similar failure case on other scenario that need to run runtime manifest?
Even if we move this logic here, it can obviously report failure operation on active controller, but could not report failure if runtime application failed on standby controller.

I am concerned about one potential case where we could have an unrecoverable failure. If platform::etcd::upgrade::runtime manifest application failed on the active controller, the "etcdcontrol auth enable" would not get run. I don't see how the system could recover from that (other than the user running the commands manually, which they wouldn't know how to do). If you do everything for the active controller in the upgrade script, if anything fails, the upgrade activation would fail. The user would then be able to do the "upgrade activate" again, which would repeat the script and allow the "etcdcontrol auth enable" to be done.

Does that make sense? It feels like it would be more robust to do everything for the active controller in the upgrade script itself.

I believe there would be a "config out of date" alarm if the runtime manifest fails to apply, but that won't give the user any info about how to correct the issue and as explained above, this would be very difficult to correct. In other cases of "config out of date", this can usually be corrected by locking/unlocking the host with the issue, but that would not correct the issue in this case.

If the runtime application failed on the standby controller, I think we would be OK, because a lock/unlock of the standby controller would cause the new etcd certificates to be copied to their correct locations.

FWIW, I had pretty good luck with a probe test along the lines of http://paste.openstack.org/show/794164/ -- though there are a couple problems:

* It demonstrates only one of at least two ways you can get dark data: tombstone got reaped then an old disk got reintroduced to the cluster. But you can get dark data without any DELETEs, too -- if all the container servers were all unavailable during the PUT, the object servers all write down async pendings. If the updaters are *really* backlogged, none of those updates land within a reclaim window and we unlink the async pending.

* Since the watcher currently only logs about dark data, it's difficult to test that it was properly identified. Maybe if we had the watcher also write the top N largest bits of dark data to recon it'd be something easier to verify?
